H0.text: Cold air molecules colliding generate heat energy as the classroom temperature rises from 15 °C to 20 °C after the teacher turns the thermostat to 20 °C and keeps the door closed.

H1.text: Cold energy in the room transforms into heat energy as the temperature in the classroom rises from 15 °C (59 °F) to 20 °C (68 °F) after the teacher turns the thermostat up and the door is kept closed.

H2.text: The room becomes warmer as heat energy is added to the room when the teacher turns the thermostat from 15 °C (59 °F) to 20 °C (68 °F) while keeping the door closed.

H3.text: The room becomes warmer as cold energy is pushed out of the room when the teacher turns the thermostat from 15 °C (59 °F) to 20 °C (68 °F) and keeps the door closed.

A4.text: A thermostat exerts control by switching heating or cooling devices on or off, or by regulating the flow of a heat transfer fluid as needed, to maintain the correct temperature.
